thread.title: Corruption Currents: Will Pursue EU Sanctions After WTO Rules for Boeing

author: Ben DiPietro
title: Corruption Currents: Will Pursue EU Sanctions After WTO Rules for Boeing
text:
0 COMMENTS A photo from March 7, 2017, shows a Boeing 737 MAX 9 airplane in Renton, Wash. Photo: Agence France-Presse/Getty Images
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
A former U.S. Border Patrol agent was given a 7-year federal prison sentence for bribery. (KTAR, ADS)
A school principal in Detroit convicted of taking a bribe had her appeal of that sentence rejected by a federal court. (AP)
A man received a six-year prison sentence for his role in a bribery scheme involving federal contracts to the Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland. (BS)
Money Laundering:
The European Commission wants member states to take stronger actions to fight money laundering. (Politico)
The tax fraud conviction of a former French budget minister was upheld by an appeals court. The decision means Jérôme Cahuzac will have to serve time in prison, pay a fine and be barred from public office for five years. (Guardian, Politico)
The central bank in Zimbabwe told financial institutions there not to provide services to people dealing in cyrptocurrencies. (BL)
Cybercrime/Privacy:
Namibia’s minister of justice says cybercrime poses a serious threat to national security. (NE)
Sanctions:
The U.S. Trade Representative said it would pursue sanctions against the European Union after the World Trade Organization ruled for the U.S. in a claim that the EU provided illegal subsidies to plane maker Airbus that harmed U.S. rival Boeing Co. (ST, Bloomberg, Reuters)
The U.S. placed sanctions on Tuesday on the head of Iran’s central bank . Congress gets a report on U.S. sanctions on Iran. (AP, Reuters, NYT, USNI)
European Union officials say they will try to shield EU companies from sanctions if they are penalized by the U.S. for doing business in Iran. An aide to French President Emmanuel Macron says Europe needs to respond strongly to the U.S. sanction threat. (Guardian, Reuters)
Russian lawmakers gave initial approval to a bill that mandates prison for anyone following U.S. sanctions. (RFE/RL, DW)
Transparency:
They’re making a movie about the Panama Papers and Meryl Streep is slated to star in it. (OCCRP, Guardian)
The attorney for porn star Stormy Daniels says he did nothing wrong when he released information about payments made by companies to the personal attorney for U.S. President Donald Trump. (Politico)
General Anticorruption:
India’s Central Bureau of Investigation filed fraud charges against two dozen people, including top banking industry executives. The article didn’t include responses from those charged. (Quartz, Pymnts)
What makes some countries more prone to corruption than others? (BI)
Nigeria’s president recounts the time he was ousted from the government and sent to prison for fighting corruption. (PT)
Prosecutors indicted the three co-founders of cryptocurrency startup Centra Tech Inc. on fraud charges. The exchange was once promoted by boxer Floyd Mayweather. (Reuters, Bloomberg, CD)
A settlement was reached in the memorabilia fraud lawsuit involving New York Giants quarterback Eli Manning. (WP, USAT, ESPN)
